subtopics.title: Introduction to Trigonometric Functions
subtopics.content:
Introduction

Trigonometry (from Greek: trigonon = triangle, metron = measure) deals with the relationship between the angles and sides of a triangle. Extending beyond right-angled triangles, trigonometric functions are defined for all real numbers using the unit circle. These functions play a key role in geometry, physics, engineering, astronomy, and calculus.

subtopics.title: Angles and Their Measurement
subtopics.content:
Angles

Angles are measured in degrees (°) and radians (rad).

180° = π radians.

General formula:

θ (in radians) = (π/180) × θ (in degrees)

subtopics.title: Trigonometric Functions on Unit Circle
subtopics.content:
Trigonometric Functions on Unit Circle

On a unit circle (circle with radius 1):

For an angle θ, if P(x, y) lies on the circle, then:

  • sin θ = y
  • cos θ = x
  • tan θ = y/x (x ≠ 0)
  • cot θ = x/y
  • sec θ = 1/x
  • csc θ = 1/y

subtopics.title: Signs of Trigonometric Functions
subtopics.content:
Signs of Trigonometric Functions (ASTC Rule)

In four quadrants:

  • I Quadrant: All positive
  • II Quadrant: Sine, cosec positive
  • III Quadrant: Tan, cot positive
  • IV Quadrant: Cos, sec positive

subtopics.title: Trigonometric Identities
subtopics.content:
Trigonometric Identities

  • sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
  • 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ
  • 1 + cot²θ = csc²θ

subtopics.title: Periodicity and Graphs
subtopics.content:
Periodicity

  • sin θ, cos θ: Period = 2π
  • tan θ, cot θ: Period = π

Graphs of Trigonometric Functions

Sine and cosine: Smooth, wave-like (bounded between -1 and 1).

Tangent and cotangent: Have vertical asymptotes.

Secant and cosecant: Reciprocal wave-like curves with asymptotes.

questions.question: Convert 150° to radians.
questions.explanation: To convert degrees to radians, multiply by π/180°. 150° × (π/180°) = 150π/180 = 5π/6 radians.

questions.question: If sin θ = 3/5 and θ is in the first quadrant, what is cos θ?
questions.explanation: Using the identity sin²θ + cos²θ = 1: (3/5)² + cos²θ = 1 → 9/25 + cos²θ = 1 → cos²θ = 16/25 → cos θ = ±4/5. Since θ is in the first quadrant, cos θ is positive, so cos θ = 4/5.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.explanation: This is one of the fundamental trigonometric identities. The other options are incorrect: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1 (not subtraction), cot²θ + 1 = csc²θ (not subtraction), and sin θ + cos θ = 1 is not generally true.

questions.question: What is the period of tan x?
questions.explanation: The tangent function has a period of π, meaning tan(x + π) = tan(x) for all x in its domain.

questions.question: If cos θ = -12/13 and θ is in the second quadrant, what is sin θ?
questions.explanation: Using sin²θ + cos²θ = 1: sin²θ + (-12/13)² = 1 → sin²θ + 144/169 = 1 → sin²θ = 25/169 → sin θ = ±5/13. Since θ is in the second quadrant, sin θ is positive, so sin θ = 5/13.

questions.question: What is sin 225°?
questions.explanation: 225° is in the third quadrant where sine is negative. 225° = 180° + 45°, so sin 225° = -sin 45° = -√2/2.

questions.question: Which of the following is not defined?
questions.explanation: tan(π/2) is undefined because cos(π/2) = 0, and tan θ = sin θ/cos θ, which would involve division by zero. The other values are all defined: sin(π/2) = 1, cos(π/2) = 0, tan(π/4) = 1.

questions.question: What is the principal value of sin⁻¹(-1/2)?
questions.explanation: The principal value of sin⁻¹x lies in the interval [-π/2, π/2]. Since sin(-π/6) = -1/2 and -π/6 is in the required interval, sin⁻¹(-1/2) = -π/6.

questions.question: If sin A = cos B, what is A + B?
questions.explanation: If sin A = cos B, then A and B are complementary angles. This is because sin θ = cos(90° - θ). So if sin A = cos B, then A = 90° - B, which means A + B = 90°.

questions.question: What is the range of y = sin x?
questions.explanation: The sine function oscillates between -1 and 1 for all real values of x. Therefore, the range of y = sin x is [-1, 1].
